citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Five black and tan goats have back hooves that are overgrown and need to be trimmed. When asked, the facility
representative stated that they had not noticed that their hooves were overgrown.
Overgrown hooves can cause pain and discomfort, and lead to abnormal gaits. Inadequate daily observations can lead to
the prolonged suffering of animals when changes in their health are not noticed in a timely manner. The licensee must
ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct
and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian. The licensee must ensure that the overgrown hooves are
trimmed.
To be corrected by February 14, 2025.

Tag 12, used to identify the adult male wolf dog hybrid “Klondike”, is missing from the outside of his enclosure.
Not having proper identification can cause misidentification of animals on inspections, veterinary care documentation,
acquisition and disposition records, as well as legal tracking. The licensee must ensure that an official USDA sequentially
numbered tag is placed on the animals with a collar or kept on the door of the animals' cage or run, or an approved tattoo
or microchip is used to positively identify the animal. If tags are maintained on the enclosure (rather than a collar) then the
licensee must have a record book containing each animal’s tag number, a written description of each animal, and a clear
photograph of each animal. Each tag must contain the letters “USDA”, the certificate number identifying the state as well
as the facility, and a number identifying the animal. A duplicate tag must also accompany each cat whenever it leaves the
premise.
To be corrected by February 14, 2025.

citations.desc: Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries.
citations.narrative:
The animals listed on the submitted itinerary for "Unit 2" do not match the animals present at the traveling exhibit location.
The itinerary submitted by the licensee listed 1 sheep, 13 goats, 8 bovine, and 1 camel; however, there are 11 sheep, 38
goats, 8 bovine, and 1 camel present during the inspection.
Failure to provide accurate information regarding animals on the itinerary makes it difficult to track what animals are being
used for regulated activity when away from the home site. The itinerary shall include the name, identification number or
identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age of each animal.
To be corrected by February 14, 2025.
This inspection was conducted on “Unit 1” and “Unit 2” at International Market World in Auburndale, Florida.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Five black and tan goats have back hooves that are overgrown and need to be trimmed. When asked, the facility 
representative stated that they had not noticed that their hooves were overgrown.  
Overgrown hooves can cause pain and discomfort, and lead to abnormal gaits. Inadequate daily observations can lead to 
the prolonged suffering of animals when changes in their health are not noticed in a timely manner. The licensee must 
ensure that all animals are observed daily to assess their health and well-being and then ensure a mechanism of direct 
and frequent communication with the attending veterinarian. The licensee must ensure that the overgrown hooves are 
trimmed. 
To be corrected by February 14, 2025. 
2.50(c)(2)(i) 
   
Time and method of identification. 
Tag 12, used to identify the adult male wolf dog hybrid “Klondike”, is missing from the outside of his enclosure. 
Not having proper identification can cause misidentification of animals on inspections, veterinary care documentation, 
acquisition and disposition records, as well as legal tracking. The licensee must ensure that an official USDA sequentially 
numbered tag is placed on the animals with a collar or kept on the door of the animals' cage or run, or an approved tattoo 
or microchip is used to positively identify the animal. If tags are maintained on the enclosure (rather than a collar) then the 
licensee must have a record book containing each animal’s tag number, a written description of each animal, and a clear 
photograph of each animal. Each tag must contain the letters “USDA”, the certificate number identifying the state as well 
as the facility, and a number identifying the animal. A duplicate tag must also accompany each cat whenever it leaves the 
premise. 
To be corrected by February 14, 2025. 
2.126(c)(1)(ii) 
   
Access and inspection of records and property; submission of itineraries. 
The animals listed on the submitted itinerary for "Unit 2" do not match the animals present at the traveling exhibit location. 
The itinerary submitted by the licensee listed 1 sheep, 13 goats, 8 bovine, and 1 camel; however, there are 11 sheep, 38 
goats, 8 bovine, and 1 camel present during the inspection.  
Failure to provide accurate information regarding animals on the itinerary makes it difficult to track what animals are being

used for regulated activity when away from the home site. The itinerary shall include the name, identification number or 
identifying characteristics, species (common or scientific name), sex and age of each animal.  
To be corrected by February 14, 2025. 
 
This inspection was conducted on “Unit 1” and “Unit 2” at International Market World in Auburndale, Florida. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee and a facility representative.
